inscribed:
Top of storage box lid:
Basket – Kago 籠
Yamada Sohen – Yamada Sohen 山田宗（偏？）
Copied after the Katsura River flower basket – Katsuragawa utsuhi hana ire 桂川寫花入
Signed with black lacquer – Kuro urushi黑漆書（付？）
Kojakuan Kansui – Kojakuan Kansui 古若菴潤水
(2 seals)

Bottom of storage box lid:
Made by Yohoan [i.e., Yamada Sohen] – Yohoan saku
Flower basket inspired by Katsuragawa	 – Katsuragawa utsushi hana ire
One of seven, signed – Meihan ari, nanatsu no uchi
signed:
Signed on storage box lid: Kakitsuke mei hai 丁丑夏
Summer of 1697

makers.displaymaker: Kojakuan Kansui 古若菴潤水, active late 17th century

texts.textentryhtml:
Sencha

The practice of sencha, or brewing "steeped tea," rose to prominence in eighteenth-century Kyoto, bringing together many of the artists featured in these galleries. Itō Jakuchū and Musen Jōzen, who collaborated on the carp painting on view here, likely developed a relationship through their participation in the burgeoning sencha community. Associated with Chinese literati culture and ideals, sencha attracted a tight-knit group of Sinophile aesthetes who appreciated the flexibility of sencha’s free-form gatherings, as opposed to the formality of Japanese tea practice (chanoyu). In the nineteenth century, sencha evolved into an established practice with codified implements, the most essential of which was a handle teapot of the sort displayed here. Seifū Yohei III descended from a family that specialized in sencha ceramics, and this thin porcelain teapot reflects the heightened aesthetic sensibility and technical craftsmanship achieved by the Seifū house during the modern era.
texts.remarks: Asian Art Rotation September 2018 (group chat for 2012-90 a-b and 2003-282 a-b)

texts.textentryhtml:
ca. 1697– Yamada Sohen I (Japan).

–2003 Koichi Yanagi of Oriental Fine Arts, Kokon, Inc. (New York, NY), sold to the Princeton University Art Museum with assistance from Lloyd E. Cotsen, 2003.

Japanese, Edo period (1603–1868), Kojakuan Kansui 古若菴潤水 (active late 17th century), Katsura River style (Katsuragawa) flower basket, 1697. Basket (a): bamboo with metal hanger
Insert (b): bamboo; 19 x 21 cm, 17.6 x 5.4 cm. Gift of Lloyd E. Cotsen, Class of 1950 (2003-282 a-b)
